services.name: Predictive Quality Control System
services.overview: The Predictive Quality Control System is an AI-powered solution designed to predict quality defects in real-time during the automotive manufacturing process. By analyzing historical production data, sensor readings from manufacturing equipment, and visual inspection data, the system identifies potential defects before they occur, allowing for proactive intervention. This reduces material waste, improves overall product quality, and optimizes the manufacturing workflow. The system provides a user-friendly interface for quality control managers, production engineers, and plant managers to monitor defect predictions, investigate root causes, and implement corrective actions. The system will be deployed on the shop floor, integrating with existing manufacturing execution systems (MES) and programmable logic controllers (PLCs) to provide real-time feedback and control. The long-term objective is to move from reactive to proactive quality control, significantly reducing the cost of quality and improving operational efficiency.
problems_addressed: High defect rates in critical manufacturing processes like welding and painting
Significant material waste due to undetected defects early in the production line
Reactive quality control processes that rely on post-production inspection and rework
Lack of real-time visibility into the quality of manufactured parts
Inability to identify the root causes of defects quickly and efficiently
target_users: Quality Control Managers: Responsible for overseeing the quality control process and ensuring product quality meets specifications.
Production Engineers: Responsible for optimizing production processes and implementing corrective actions to reduce defects.
Plant Managers: Responsible for overall plant performance, including quality metrics and production efficiency.
core_features: Real-time Defect Prediction: Machine learning models analyze sensor data, process parameters, and visual inspection data to predict potential defects in real-time, displayed on a dashboard with severity scores and potential impact.

Alerting and Notifications: Automated alerts and notifications are triggered when a defect is predicted, notifying relevant personnel (e.g., production engineers, quality control managers) via email, SMS, or integration with existing MES systems. Alerts are configurable based on severity and location.

Root Cause Analysis: The system provides tools for investigating the root causes of predicted defects, including data visualization, correlation analysis, and drill-down capabilities to identify contributing factors.  Includes automated suggestions for potential causes based on historical data.

Process Parameter Optimization: The system recommends adjustments to process parameters (e.g., welding voltage, paint flow rate) to prevent predicted defects, based on the models' learned relationships. Provides A/B testing framework for validating recommendations.

Historical Data Analysis: Comprehensive historical data analysis capabilities to identify trends, patterns, and correlations related to defects.  Includes customizable reporting and data export functionality for offline analysis.
Visual Inspection Integration:  Ability to integrate with existing camera systems on the production line to analyze images for visual defects, flagging potential issues for further review.
user_journeys: A quality control manager logs into the system dashboard, views real-time defect predictions for the welding process, sees a high-severity prediction for a potential weld defect on a car chassis, receives an automated alert, drills down into the data to identify the contributing factors (e.g., inconsistent welding voltage), notifies a production engineer, who adjusts the welding parameters, and the system confirms that the defect prediction has been mitigated.
ai_capabilities: The system utilizes machine learning models trained on historical production data (e.g., sensor readings from welding machines, paint booths), visual inspection data (images of parts), and process parameters (e.g., welding voltage, paint flow rate).

Specifically, uses a combination of Random Forest, XGBoost, and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). Random Forest and XGBoost are used for tabular sensor data and process parameters to predict defects. CNNs are used to analyze images from visual inspection systems to detect surface defects. Models are regularly retrained using new data to improve accuracy.

Consider using OpenAI's GPT models for anomaly detection in text-based process logs. Embeddings will be used to vectorize unstructured data. Vector search (Pinecone/Supabase vectors) will be used to find similar past defect scenarios and potential solutions.  Fine-tuning will be considered if labeled defect data is plentiful and specific to the manufacturing process.

input_data_types: Sensor readings from manufacturing equipment (e.g., voltage, current, temperature, pressure)
Process parameters (e.g., welding speed, paint flow rate, oven temperature)
Historical defect data (defect type, location, severity)
Production logs (timestamps, operator IDs, machine IDs)
data_schema_recommendations: Defects Table: defect_id (INT, PRIMARY KEY), timestamp (TIMESTAMP), machine_id (VARCHAR), part_id (VARCHAR), defect_type (VARCHAR), severity (ENUM('low', 'medium', 'high')), predicted (BOOLEAN), confidence_score (FLOAT)
Sensor Readings Table: reading_id (INT, PRIMARY KEY), timestamp (TIMESTAMP), machine_id (VARCHAR), sensor_type (VARCHAR), sensor_value (FLOAT)
Process Parameters Table: parameter_id (INT, PRIMARY KEY), timestamp (TIMESTAMP), machine_id (VARCHAR), parameter_name (VARCHAR), parameter_value (FLOAT)
Images Table: image_id (INT, PRIMARY KEY), timestamp (TIMESTAMP), machine_id (VARCHAR), part_id (VARCHAR), image_path (VARCHAR)
data_sources: Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) on manufacturing equipment
data_requirements.privacy_and_compliance: Data privacy regulations (e.g., GDPR) may apply if the system collects personal data related to operators or employees.  Ensure data is anonymized or pseudonymized where appropriate. Compliance with industry-specific standards (e.g., ISO 9001) should be considered.

required_integrations: Manufacturing Execution System (MES) – for real-time production data and workflow integration.
Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) – for direct access to sensor readings from manufacturing equipment.
ERP system – for integration with inventory management and supply chain data.
Email provider (e.g., SendGrid, Mailgun) – for sending alerts and notifications.
Analytics tools (e.g., Google Analytics, Mixpanel) – for tracking user engagement and system performance.
integration_plan.authentication_strategy: JWT (JSON Web Tokens) for secure authentication and authorization. Consider using Clerk or Auth0 for user management and authentication.

technical_specifications.architecture: The system will follow a microservices architecture, consisting of an API layer, a frontend, a backend, a database, and an AI pipeline. The API layer will provide endpoints for accessing data and triggering actions. The frontend will provide a user interface for monitoring defect predictions and investigating root causes. The backend will handle data processing, model training, and API requests. The database will store historical production data, sensor readings, and defect information. The AI pipeline will be responsible for training and deploying machine learning models.

recommended_tech_stack.frontend: Next.js 14 App Router, TailwindCSS, shadcn/ui, Vercel conventions
recommended_tech_stack.backend: Node.js / Next.js server actions / Vercel serverless functions
recommended_tech_stack.database: Planetscale / Supabase / PostgreSQL with schema notes (see data_schema_recommendations)
recommended_tech_stack.storage: Supabase storage / AWS S3 / Vercel Blob for storing images and other large files.
recommended_tech_stack.AI: OpenAI API for text analysis, embeddings, and anomaly detection; Vector DB (Pinecone/Supabase vectors) for similarity search; scikit-learn, TensorFlow, or PyTorch for model training and deployment.
recommended_tech_stack.APIs: REST APIs for communication between frontend, backend, and external systems.

API_design: /api/defects (GET): Returns a list of predicted defects, with optional filters (e.g., machine_id, defect_type, severity). Payload: { machine_id: string, defect_type: string, severity: string }
/api/defects/{defect_id} (GET): Returns details for a specific defect. Payload: None
/api/sensors (GET): Returns sensor readings for a specific machine and time range. Payload: { machine_id: string, start_time: timestamp, end_time: timestamp }
/api/parameters (GET): Returns process parameters for a specific machine and time range. Payload: { machine_id: string, start_time: timestamp, end_time: timestamp }
/api/recommendations (POST):  Returns recommended parameter adjustments to mitigate a predicted defect. Payload: { defect_id: int }
/api/images/{image_id} (GET): Returns image data for a specific image. Payload: None
frontend_components: Dashboard: Displays real-time defect predictions, key performance indicators (KPIs), and system status.
Defect Details View: Provides detailed information about a specific defect, including contributing factors and recommended actions.
Sensor Data Visualization: Displays sensor readings and process parameters over time, allowing users to identify trends and patterns.
Alerting and Notification Panel: Displays a list of active alerts and notifications.
Image Viewer: Displays images related to defects, with zoom and annotation capabilities

deployment_instructions: Environment variables: OPENAI_API_KEY, DB_URL, SUPABASE_URL, SUPABASE_ANON_KEY, SENDGRID_API_KEY
Vercel deployment: Connect GitHub repository to Vercel. Configure environment variables in Vercel settings. Enable automatic deployments on Git push.
Build outputs: Next.js frontend, Node.js backend serverless functions, Trained AI models (saved as .pkl or .h5 files). Runtime settings: Node.js 18, Python 3.9 for AI model serving.

pricing_strategy: SaaS subscription tiers: Basic, Standard, Premium.
Usage-based pricing: Charge per predicted defect or per analysis performed.
Add-ons: Integration with specific MES systems, custom model training.
customer_segments: Large automotive manufacturers with multiple plants

success_metrics: Improvement in product quality (Defect parts per million)
Accuracy of defect predictions (Precision, Recall, F1-score)
Adoption rate of the system by quality control managers and production engineers
Time to identify and resolve defects (Mean Time To Resolution - MTTR)
